description: The Titans represent the primordial generation of divine beings in Greek mythology, preceding the Olympian gods. Born from the union of Gaia (Earth) and Uranus (Sky), these twelve original Titans and their descendants embodied the fundamental forces of the cosmos - time, memory, ocean, light, and celestial phenomena. Under the rule of Cronus, the Titans presided over the mythological Golden Age before being overthrown by Zeus and the Olympians in the cataclysmic Titanomachy. The defeated Titans were cast into Tartarus, though some like Prometheus and Atlas received individual punishments. Their mythology explores themes of generational conflict, cosmic succession, and the transition from primordial chaos to ordered divine rule that shaped Greek religious thought.

sections.origins: The Titans emerged from the primordial union of Gaia (Earth) and Uranus (Sky), representing the first generation of anthropomorphic gods in Greek cosmology. Gaia, weary of Uranus imprisoning her monstrous children (the Cyclopes and Hundred-Handed Ones) in her depths, conspired with her youngest Titan son Cronus to overthrow his father. Using an adamantine sickle provided by Gaia, Cronus castrated Uranus, separating sky from earth and establishing Titan dominion over the cosmos.
sections.attributes: Each Titan personified cosmic forces: Oceanus embodied the world-encircling river, Hyperion represented celestial light, Mnemosyne was memory itself, and Cronus wielded power over time and agriculture. Their immense size and power exceeded that of later Olympians, with Atlas capable of bearing the weight of the heavens and Prometheus possessing the foresight to see the future of gods and men.
sections.significance: The Titans represent a transitional phase in Greek cosmogony between primordial chaos and ordered Olympian rule. Their mythology established the pattern of divine succession through conflict that defined Greek religious thought. Prometheus' creation and protection of humanity made the Titans essential to human origins, while their fall illustrated the inevitability of change and the dangers of tyrannical rule.
sections.impact: Titan mythology profoundly influenced Western literature, from Milton's Paradise Lost to Shelley's Prometheus Unbound. The term 'titanic' entered common usage to describe anything of enormous size or power. Their stories continue to resonate in modern fantasy literature, films, and games, representing themes of rebellion against authority and the cost of defying divine order.
